title: Ryan Brant’s Art Collection, Including Over 25 Works by KAWS, Heads to Auction
text:
Text size

Property from the collection of video game executive Ryan Brant, including some 25 works by KAWS, will be offered across a series of sales at Sotheby’s from Sept. 26 to spring 2020.

Brant, founder of video game publisher Take-Two Interactive, which developed some of the world’s most recognized video games, including Grand Theft Auto, Red Dead, and NBA 2K, assembled a significant collection of paintings, decorative arts, and furniture during his life. He died in March at age 47.

Brant grew up in a collecting family, “in an environment of immense creativity and aesthetic stimulation,” Sotheby’s said. His father, Peter Brant, was an early collector of Andy Warhol and a major collector of Franz Kline, and former publisher of Art in America magazine, which merged with ARTnews in 2015.

“As is befitting a successful creative entrepreneur, Ryan was ahead of the curve in his appreciation for cutting-edge contemporary artists—most especially as an early collector and advocate of KAWS,” said Amy Cappellazzo, chairman of Sotheby’s fine art division, in a statement.

Sotheby’s will offer over 130 items from Brant’s collection, beginning with three works by KAWS, Don’t Sink, Untitled (HTLB1), and Untitled, at a New York auction on Sept. 26, titled Contemporary Curated.

“Upon first glance, it is clear that Ryan possessed a very distinct yet playful eye,” says Charlotte Van Dercook, head of Sotheby’s Contemporary Curated auctions in New York. “From vibrant, colorful works by KAWS to a whimsical, large-scale canvas by Francesco Clemente, the pieces on offer in our sale illustrate the avant-garde approach that he applied not only to collecting art, but also his pioneering vision as the founder of Take-Two Interactive.”

The Skull by Francesco Clemente Courtesy of Sotheby's

Don’t Sink by KAWS has a high estimate of $350,000, and The Skull by Clemente is estimated to fetch up to $80,000.

Two additional works by KAWS will be included in Sotheby’s Hong Kong sale of contemporary art from Oct. 6-7. Untitled (MBFR) has a high estimate of HK$6.2 million (US$795,000), while Untitled is estimated to sell for as high as HK$3.5 million ($447,000).

Works by KAWS, the New Jersey-born artist also known as Brian Donnelly, have a big appeal to Asian collectors, especially those from younger generations. In April, his painting, The Kaws Album (2005), sold for HK$115.9 million (about US$14.7 million) at Sotheby’s Hong Kong, setting an auction record for the artist.

KAWS is a graffiti-artist-turned-fine-artist. He is known for subverting American iconic cartoon characters, including The Simpsons, Mickey Mouse, the Michelin Man, the Smurfs, Snoopy, and SpongeBob SquarePants.

Furniture from the collection of Ryan Brant will be offered at Sotheby’s sale of important design in New York on Dec. 12. Other items will be included throughout Sotheby’s auctions into next spring.
description: Over 130 pieces from the video game executive will be offered in a series of sales at Sotheby’s
